For the North Western Plains Zone, the fertilizer application requirements are NPK in the quantity of 150:60:40 kg per hectare at the time of sowing. For the North Eastern Plains Zone, the fertilizer application requirements are NPK in the quantity of 150:60:40 kg per hectare at the time of sowing. For the Central Zone, the fertilizer application requirements are NPK in the quantity of 120:60:40 kg per hectare at the time of sowing. For the Peninsular Zone, the fertilizer application requirements are NPK in the quantity of 120:60:40 kg per hectare at the time of sowing. For the Southern Hills Zone, the fertilizer application requirements are NPK in the quantity of 120:60:40 kg per hectare at the time of sowing.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: The different CropGrowingZones for wheat cultivation include the North Western Plains Zone, North Eastern Plains Zone, Central Zone, Peninsular Zone, Northern Hills Zone, and Southern Hills Zone. Each zone has specific seed recommendations. For example, the North Western Plains Zone recommends varieties like KRL 19, PBW 502, PBW 527, PDW 291, PBW 550, HD 2967, PDW 314, WHD 943, DPW 621-50. The North Eastern Plains Zone recommends varieties like KRL 19, PBW 343, PBW 443, HD 2733, MACS 6145, HD 2824, HD 2888, K 307, DBW 17, Raj 4120, CBW 38, HD 2967, DBW 39, MACS 6222, KRL 210, KRL 213, K 9162, K 7903, K 9533, DBW 252, DBW 187, HD 3086, HPBW 2/(+Fe/Zn), PBW 550, PBW 550 Unnat. The Central Zone recommends varieties like KRL 19, GW 1139, GW 322, HI 1500, HI 8627, HI 1531, GW 366, HI 8498, HI 1544, MACS 2971, MPO 1215, MP 3288, HI 8713, HI 8737, DBW 110, MPO 1106, HI 1479, DDW 47, DBW 110. The Peninsular Zone recommends varieties like GW 322, HD 2781, GW 1189, NIDW 295, Raj 4037, DDK 1025, NIAW 917, AKDW 2997-16, DDK 1029, HI 8663, AKAW 3722, MACS 2971, PBW 596, UAS 415, HD 2987, NIAW 1415, UAS 428, NIAW 301, MACS 3125, DBW 168, DBW 93. The Northern Hills Zone recommends varieties like VL 829, HPW 251, VL 907, VL 804, HPW 155, HS 375, SKW 196, VL 832, TL 2942, HS 507, HPW 349, HS 420, VL 892, HS 490. The Southern Hills Zone recommends varieties like HW 2044, HW 5216.

growth, wilting', 'pest_control': [{'@type': 'PesticideList', 'name': 'Chlorpyrifos', 'quantity': '2.5 ml/litre of water', 'stage': 'At the time of pest appearance'}]}, 'harvesting_guidelines_are': 'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: The different CropGrowingZones for wheat and their specific seed recommendations are: 1) North Western Plains Zone with seed varieties like KRL 19, PBW 502, PBW 527, PDW 291, PBW 550, HD 2967, PDW 314, WHD 943, DPW 621-50. 2) North Eastern Plains Zone with seed varieties like KRL 19, PBW 343, PBW 443, HD 2733, MACS 6145, HD 2824, HD 2888, K 307, DBW 17, Raj 4120, CBW 38, HD 2967, DBW 39, MACS 6222, KRL 210, KRL 213, K 9162, K 7903, K 9533, DBW 252, DBW 187, HD 3086, HPBW 2/(+Fe/Zn), PBW 550, PBW 550 Unnat. 3) Central Zone with seed varieties like KRL 19, GW 1139, GW 322, HI 1500, HI 8627, HI 1531, GW 366, HI 8498, HI 1544, MACS 2971, MPO 1215, MP 3288, HI 8713, HI 8737, DBW 110, MPO 1106, HI 1479, DDW 47, DBW 110. 4) Peninsular Zone with seed varieties like GW 322, HD 2781, GW 1189, NIDW 295, Raj 4037, DDK 1025, NIAW 917, AKDW 2997-16, DDK 1029, HI 8663, AKAW 3722, MACS 2971, PBW 596, UAS 415, HD 2987, NIAW 1415, UAS 428, NIAW 301, MACS 3125, DBW 168, DBW 93. 5) Northern Hills Zone with seed varieties like VL 829, HPW 251, VL 907, VL 804, HPW 155, HS 375, SKW 196, VL 832, TL 2942, HS 507, HPW 349, HS 420, VL 892, HS 490. 6) Southern Hills Zone with seed varieties like HW 2044, HW 5216.

ground_truth: For the Northern Hills Zone, the recommended seed variety is NHZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-01 to 2022-11-20 and late sowing time from 2022-11-25 to 2022-12-15. The seeding rate is 100 kg per hectare. For the North Western Plains Zone, the recommended seed variety is NWPZ, with similar sowing times and seeding rate. For the North Eastern Plains Zone, the recommended seed variety is NEPZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-10 to 2022-11-25 and late sowing time from 2022-11-25 to 2022-12-15. The seeding rate is the same. For the Central Zone, the recommended seed variety is CZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-10 to 2022-11-30 and late sowing time from 2022-12-01 to 2022-12-15. The seeding rate is the same. For the Peninsular Zone, the recommended seed variety is PZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-01 to 2022-11-25 and late sowing time from 2022-11-25 to 2022-12-10. The seeding rate is the same. For the Southern Hills Zone, the recommended seed variety is SHZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-15 to 2022-11-30 and late sowing time from 2022-12-01 to 2022-12-15. The seeding rate is the same.

ground_truth: The different crop growing zones for wheat in India include the Northern Hills Zone, North Western Plains Zone, North Eastern Plains Zone, Central Zone, Peninsular Zone, and Southern Hills Zone.

ground_truth: For the 'Northern Hills Zone', the recommended seed variety is 'NHZ' with a seeding rate of '100 kg per hectare'. The early sowing time is from '2022-11-01' to '2022-11-20' and the late sowing time is from '2022-11-25' to '2022-12-15'. The fertilizer application requirement is 'NPK' with a quantity of '120:60:40 kg per hectare' at the time of sowing. For the 'North Western Plains Zone', the recommended seed variety is 'NWPZ' with the same seeding rate and sowing times. The fertilizer requirement is 'NPK' with a quantity of '150:60:40 kg per hectare'. For the 'North Eastern Plains Zone', the recommended seed variety is 'NEPZ' with the same seeding rate and fertilizer requirement as the 'North Western Plains Zone'. The early sowing time is from '2022-11-10' to '2022-11-25' and the late sowing time is from '2022-11-25' to '2022-12-15'. For the 'Central Zone', the recommended seed variety is 'CZ' with a seeding rate of '100 kg per hectare'. The early sowing time is from '2022-11-10' to '2022-11-30' and the late sowing time is from '2022-12-01' to '2022-12-15'. The fertilizer application requirement is 'NPK' with a quantity of '120:60:40 kg per hectare' at the time of sowing. For the 'Peninsular Zone', the recommended seed variety is 'PZ' with the same seeding rate and fertilizer requirement as the 'Central Zone'. The early sowing time is from '2022-11-01' to '2022-11-25' and the late sowing time is from '2022-11-25' to '2022-12-10'. For the 'Southern Hills Zone', the recommended seed variety is 'SHZ' with the same seeding rate and fertilizer requirement as the 'Central Zone'. The early sowing time is from '2022-11-15' to '2022-11-30' and the late sowing time is from '2022-12-01' to '2022-12-15'.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: The 'Zero tillage' method in wheat farming is used for directly placing wheat seed and fertilizers at proper depth into the undisturbed soil after rice harvesting. This is done using a specially designed machine which creates narrow slits by the knife type furrow openers of zero tillage ferti-seed drill instead of shovel type furrow opener in conventional ferti-seed drill.

ground_truth: When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.

ground_truth: For the Northern Hills Zone, the recommended seed variety is NHZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-01 to 2022-11-20 and late sowing time from 2022-11-25 to 2022-12-15. The seeding rate is 100 kg per hectare. For the North Western Plains Zone, the recommended seed variety is NWPZ, with similar sowing times and seeding rate. For the North Eastern Plains Zone, the recommended seed variety is NEPZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-10 to 2022-11-25 and late sowing time from 2022-11-25 to 2022-12-15. The seeding rate is also 100 kg per hectare. For the Central Zone, the recommended seed variety is CZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-10 to 2022-11-30 and late sowing time from 2022-12-01 to 2022-12-15. The seeding rate is 100 kg per hectare. For the Peninsular Zone, the recommended seed variety is PZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-01 to 2022-11-25 and late sowing time from 2022-11-25 to 2022-12-10. The seeding rate is 100 kg per hectare. For the Southern Hills Zone, the recommended seed variety is SHZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-15 to 2022-11-30 and late sowing time from 2022-12-01 to 2022-12-15. The seeding rate is 100 kg per hectare.

growth, wilting', 'pest_control': [{'@type': 'PesticideList', 'name': 'Chlorpyrifos', 'quantity': '2.5 ml/litre of water', 'stage': 'At the time of pest appearance'}]}, 'harvesting_guidelines_are': 'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: For pests such as Aphids, Termites, Cutworms, which cause symptoms like yellowing of leaves, stunted growth, and wilting, the pesticide Chlorpyrifos is recommended. It should be applied at a quantity of 2.5 ml per litre of water at the time of pest appearance.

ground_truth: The temperature requirements for the growth of wheat are 10-15°C for germination, 20-25°C for flowering, and 15-20°C for grain filling. Temperatures above 35°C have a negative effect.

ground_truth: Wheat requires a temperature of 20-23 o C for germination and excessively high or low temperatures and drought are harmful for flowering. The grain filling stage is very crucial for yield and temperatures above 25 o C during this period tend to depress grain weight. The soil should be of clay loam or loam texture, with good structure and moderate water holding capacity. Very porous and excessively drained soils, heavy soil with poor structure and poor drainage should be avoided. The field should be leveled and one ploughing with mould board plough should be done. After that 2-3 cross harrowings followed by planking. If there is less moisture in the field, then the field should be irrigated before sowing and prepared by running harrow/cultivator if there is suitable moisture. Seed germination test should be conducted to ensure minimum 85% germination. The seeds should be treated with fungicides like Carboxin, Carbendazim, Tebuconazole, Trichoderma viride. The sowing spacing should be 20-22 cm for timely sown and 15-18 cm for late sown at a depth of 4 to 5 cm. The crop requires 4 to 6 irrigations, particularly at the crown root initiation and flowering stages.

ground_truth: The wheat crop has several growing zones including the Northern Hills Zone, North Western Plains Zone, North Eastern Plains Zone, Central Zone, Peninsular Zone, and Southern Hills Zone. Each zone has specific seed recommendations, sowing times, seeding rates, and fertilizer application requirements. For example, in the Northern Hills Zone, the recommended variety is NHZ, with an early sowing time between November 1 and November 20, and a late sowing time between November 25 and December 15. The seeding rate is 100 kg per hectare, and the fertilizer application requirement is NPK at a quantity of 120:60:40 kg per hectare, applied at the time of sowing. Similar recommendations are provided for the other zones. The crop also has specific temperature, soil, and land preparation requirements, as well as requirements for seed germination testing, seed fungicide, seed sowing spacing, weed management, irrigation, disease and pest treatments, harvesting, and storage.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: The 'Zero tillage' method in wheat cultivation is used for directly placing wheat seed and fertilizers at proper depth into the undisturbed soil after rice harvesting. This is done using a specially designed machine which creates narrow slits by the knife type furrow openers of zero tillage ferti-seed drill instead of shovel type furrow opener in conventional ferti-seed drill.

ground_truth: Wheat is used for food production and can be grown in various zones including the Northern Hills Zone, North Western Plains Zone, North Eastern Plains Zone, Central Zone, Peninsular Zone, and Southern Hills Zone. Each zone has specific seed recommendations, sowing times, seeding rates, and fertilizer application requirements. The temperature requirements for wheat include 20-23 degrees Celsius for germination, and temperatures above 25 degrees Celsius during grain filling and development can depress grain weight. The soil requirements include clay loam or loam texture, good structure, and moderate water holding capacity. The land should be leveled and ploughed, followed by 2-3 cross harrowings and planking. Seed germination test should be conducted to ensure a minimum of 85% germination. The seeds should be treated with fungicides like Carboxin, Carbendazim, Tebuconazole, or Trichoderma viride. The sowing spacing should be 20-22 cm for timely sown and 15-18 cm for late sown, with a depth of 4 to 5 cm. Weed management, irrigation schedule, disease treatments, pest treatments, harvesting guidelines, and storage guidelines are also specified.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: Wheat requires a temperature of 10-15°C for germination, 20-25°C for flowering, and 15-20°C for grain filling. Temperatures above 35°C can have a negative effect. The soil should be loamy, well-drained, and rich in organic matter. Sandy soil should be avoided. The land should be prepared with medium soil moisture. Wheat seed and fertilizers are directly placed at proper depth into the undisturbed soil after rice harvesting using a specially designed machine. The seeds should be treated with Carbendazim fungicide. The sowing time is in winter, with a spacing of 15-20 cm and a depth of 3-4 cm. The method used is drilling. The crop requires 5-6 irrigations at different stages. Diseases like Rust, Smut, Blight can be treated with Propiconazole. Pests like Aphids, Termites, Cutworms can be controlled with Chlorpyrifos. Harvesting should be done when the moisture level of grain is 25%. The grain should be dried to a moisture level below 12% before storage. For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets.

ground_truth: The Happy seeder is a tractor mounted machine that cuts and lifts paddy straw, sows wheat seed into the bare soil and deposits the straw over the sown area as mulch.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: The 'Zero tillage' method in wheat cultivation is used for directly placing wheat seed and fertilizers at proper depth into the undisturbed soil after rice harvesting. This is done using a specially designed machine which creates narrow slits by the knife type furrow openers of zero tillage ferti-seed drill instead of shovel type furrow opener in conventional ferti-seed drill.

Jointing Stage (65 DAS), Booting Stage (85 DAS), Milking Stage (105 DAS), Dough Stage (120 DAS)'}, 'needs_disease_treatements': {'@type': 'DiseaseTreatements', 'disease_name': 'Rust, Smut, Blight', 'disease_symptoms': 'Yellowing of leaves, stunted growth, black/brown spots on leaves', 'disease_control': [{'@type': 'HerbicideList', 'name': 'Propiconazole', 'quantity': '1 ml/litre of water', 'stage': 'At the time of disease appearance'}]}, 'needs_pest_treatements': {'@type': 'PestTreatements', 'pest_name': 'Aphids, Termites, Cutworms', 'pest_symptoms': 'Yellowing of leaves, stunted growth, wilting', 'pest_control': [{'@type': 'PesticideList', 'name': 'Chlorpyrifos', 'quantity': '2.5 ml/litre of water', 'stage': 'At the time of pest appearance'}]}, 'harvesting_guidelines_are': 'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: The different CropGrowingZones for wheat cultivation include the North Western Plains Zone, North Eastern Plains Zone, Central Zone, Peninsular Zone, Northern Hills Zone, and Southern Hills Zone. Each zone has specific seed recommendations. For example, the North Western Plains Zone recommends varieties like KRL 19, PBW 502, PBW 527, PDW 291, PBW 550, HD 2967, PDW 314, WHD 943, DPW 621-50. The North Eastern Plains Zone recommends varieties like KRL 19, PBW 343, PBW 443, HD 2733, MACS 6145, HD 2824, HD 2888, K 307, DBW 17, Raj 4120, CBW 38, HD 2967, DBW 39, MACS 6222, KRL 210, KRL 213, K 9162, K 7903, K 9533, DBW 252, DBW 187, HD 3086, HPBW 2/(+Fe/Zn), PBW 550, PBW 550 Unnat. The Central Zone recommends varieties like KRL 19, GW 1139, GW 322, HI 1500, HI 8627, HI 1531, GW 366, HI 8498, HI 1544, MACS 2971, MPO 1215, MP 3288, HI 8713, HI 8737, DBW 110, MPO 1106, HI 1479, DDW 47, DBW 110. The Peninsular Zone recommends varieties like GW 322, HD 2781, GW 1189, NIDW 295, Raj 4037, DDK 1025, NIAW 917, AKDW 2997-16, DDK 1029, HI 8663, AKAW 3722, MACS 2971, PBW 596, UAS 415, HD 2987, NIAW 1415, UAS 428, NIAW 301, MACS 3125, DBW 168, DBW 93. The Northern Hills Zone recommends varieties like VL 829, HPW 251, VL 907, VL 804, HPW 155, HS 375, SKW 196, VL 832, TL 2942, HS 507, HPW 349, HS 420, VL 892, HS 490. The Southern Hills Zone recommends varieties like HW 2044, HW 5216.

ground_truth: The different crop growing zones for wheat in India include the Northern Hills Zone, North Western Plains Zone, North Eastern Plains Zone, Central Zone, Peninsular Zone, and Southern Hills Zone. For the Northern Hills Zone, the recommended seed variety is NHZ, with a seeding rate of 100 kg per hectare and NPK fertilizer application of 120:60:40 kg per hectare. The North Western Plains Zone recommends the NWPZ seed variety, with the same seeding rate and an NPK fertilizer application of 150:60:40 kg per hectare. The North Eastern Plains Zone recommends the NEPZ seed variety, with the same seeding rate and NPK fertilizer application as the North Western Plains Zone. The Central Zone recommends the CZ seed variety, with the same seeding rate and an NPK fertilizer application of 120:60:40 kg per hectare. The Peninsular Zone recommends the PZ seed variety, with the same seeding rate and NPK fertilizer application as the Central Zone. Lastly, the Southern Hills Zone recommends the SHZ seed variety, with the same seeding rate and NPK fertilizer application as the Central and Peninsular Zones.

ground_truth: Wheat is used for food production and can be grown in various zones including the Northern Hills Zone, North Western Plains Zone, North Eastern Plains Zone, Central Zone, Peninsular Zone, and Southern Hills Zone. Each zone has specific seed recommendations, sowing times, seeding rates, and fertilizer application requirements. The temperature requirements for wheat include 20-23 degrees Celsius for germination, and temperatures above 25 degrees Celsius during grain filling and development can depress grain weight. The soil requirements include clay loam or loam texture, good structure, and moderate water holding capacity. The land should be leveled and ploughed, followed by 2-3 cross harrowings and planking. Seed germination test should be conducted to ensure a minimum of 85% germination. The seeds should be treated with fungicides like Carboxin, Carbendazim, Tebuconazole, or Trichoderma viride. The sowing spacing should be 20-22 cm for timely sown and 15-18 cm for late sown, with a depth of 4 to 5 cm. Weed management, irrigation schedule, disease treatments, pest treatments, harvesting guidelines, and storage guidelines are also specified.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: The different growing zones for wheat cultivation in India include the Northern Hills Zone, North Western Plains Zone, North Eastern Plains Zone, Central Zone, Peninsular Zone, and Southern Hills Zone.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: The different growing zones for wheat cultivation in India include the Northern Hills Zone, North Western Plains Zone, North Eastern Plains Zone, Central Zone, Peninsular Zone, and Southern Hills Zone.

Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. ground_truth: The temperature requirements for the growth of wheat are 10-15°C for germination, 20-25°C for flowering, and 15-20°C for grain filling. Temperatures above 35°C have a negative effect on the growth of wheat.

ground_truth: For the Northern Hills Zone, the recommended seed variety is NHZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-01 to 2022-11-20 and late sowing time from 2022-11-25 to 2022-12-15. For the North Western Plains Zone, the recommended seed variety is NWPZ, with similar sowing times. For the North Eastern Plains Zone, the recommended seed variety is NEPZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-10 to 2022-11-25 and late sowing time from 2022-11-25 to 2022-12-15. For the Central Zone, the recommended seed variety is CZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-10 to 2022-11-30 and late sowing time from 2022-12-01 to 2022-12-15. For the Peninsular Zone, the recommended seed variety is PZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-01 to 2022-11-25 and late sowing time from 2022-11-25 to 2022-12-10. For the Southern Hills Zone, the recommended seed variety is SHZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-15 to 2022-11-30 and late sowing time from 2022-12-01 to 2022-12-15.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: The different CropGrowingZones for wheat cultivation include the North Western Plains Zone, North Eastern Plains Zone, Central Zone, Peninsular Zone, Northern Hills Zone, and Southern Hills Zone. Each zone has specific seed recommendations. For example, the North Western Plains Zone recommends varieties like KRL 19, PBW 502, PBW 527, PDW 291, PBW 550, HD 2967, PDW 314, WHD 943, DPW 621-50. The North Eastern Plains Zone recommends varieties like KRL 19, PBW 343, PBW 443, HD 2733, MACS 6145, HD 2824, HD 2888, K 307, DBW 17, Raj 4120, CBW 38, HD 2967, DBW 39, MACS 6222, KRL 210, KRL 213, K 9162, K 7903, K 9533, DBW 252, DBW 187, HD 3086, HPBW 2/(+Fe/Zn), PBW 550, PBW 550 Unnat. The Central Zone recommends varieties like KRL 19, GW 1139, GW 322, HI 1500, HI 8627, HI 1531, GW 366, HI 8498, HI 1544, MACS 2971, MPO 1215, MP 3288, HI 8713, HI 8737, DBW 110, MPO 1106, HI 1479, DDW 47, DBW 110. The Peninsular Zone recommends varieties like GW 322, HD 2781, GW 1189, NIDW 295, Raj 4037, DDK 1025, NIAW 917, AKDW 2997-16, DDK 1029, HI 8663, AKAW 3722, MACS 2971, PBW 596, UAS 415, HD 2987, NIAW 1415, UAS 428, NIAW 301, MACS 3125, DBW 168, DBW 93. The Northern Hills Zone recommends varieties like VL 829, HPW 251, VL 907, VL 804, HPW 155, HS 375, SKW 196, VL 832, TL 2942, HS 507, HPW 349, HS 420, VL 892, HS 490. The Southern Hills Zone recommends varieties like HW 2044, HW 5216.

ground_truth: Wheat is used for food production and can be grown in various zones including the Northern Hills Zone, North Western Plains Zone, North Eastern Plains Zone, Central Zone, Peninsular Zone, and Southern Hills Zone. Each zone has specific seed recommendations, sowing times, seeding rates, and fertilizer application requirements. The temperature requirements for wheat include a germination temperature of 20-23 degrees Celsius, and temperatures above 25 degrees Celsius during grain filling and development can depress grain weight. The soil requirements include a clay loam or loam texture with good structure and moderate water holding capacity. The field should be leveled and ploughed with one ploughing with a mould board plough, followed by 2-3 cross harrowings and planking. Seed germination test should be conducted to ensure a minimum of 85% germination. The seeds should be treated with fungicides like Carboxin, Carbendazim, Tebuconazole, or Trichoderma viride. The sowing spacing should be 20-22 cm for timely sown and 15-18 cm for late sown, with a depth of 4 to 5 cm. Weed management, irrigation schedule, disease treatments, pest treatments, harvesting guidelines, and storage guidelines are also specified.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: The Happy seeder is a tractor mounted machine that cuts and lifts paddy straw, sows wheat seed into the bare soil and deposits the straw over the sown area as mulch.

ground_truth: For the Northern Hills Zone, the recommended seed variety is NHZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-01 to 2022-11-20 and late sowing time from 2022-11-25 to 2022-12-15. The seeding rate is 100 kg per hectare. For the North Western Plains Zone, the recommended seed variety is NWPZ, with similar sowing times and seeding rate. For the North Eastern Plains Zone, the recommended seed variety is NEPZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-10 to 2022-11-25 and late sowing time from 2022-11-25 to 2022-12-15. The seeding rate is the same. For the Central Zone, the recommended seed variety is CZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-10 to 2022-11-30 and late sowing time from 2022-12-01 to 2022-12-15. The seeding rate is the same. For the Peninsular Zone, the recommended seed variety is PZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-01 to 2022-11-25 and late sowing time from 2022-11-25 to 2022-12-10. The seeding rate is the same. For the Southern Hills Zone, the recommended seed variety is SHZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-15 to 2022-11-30 and late sowing time from 2022-12-01 to 2022-12-15. The seeding rate is the same.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. ground_truth: Wheat requires a temperature of 10-15°C for germination, 20-25°C for flowering, and 15-20°C for grain filling. Temperatures above 35°C have a negative effect. The soil should be loamy, well-drained, and rich in organic matter. Sandy soil should be avoided. The land should be prepared by placing wheat seed and fertilizers at proper depth into the undisturbed soil after rice harvesting using a specially designed machine. The soil moisture should be medium. The seed should be treated with Carbendazim fungicide. The seed sowing spacing should be 15-20 cm with a depth of 3-4 cm. The crop should be protected from weeds like Phalaris minor and diseases like Rust, Smut, and Blight. The crop requires 5-6 irrigations at different stages. The crop should be harvested when the moisture level of grain is 25% and stored properly.

ground_truth: For the Northern Hills Zone, the recommended variety is NHZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-01 to 2022-11-20 and late sowing time from 2022-11-25 to 2022-12-15. The seeding rate is 100 kg per hectare. For the North Western Plains Zone, the recommended variety is NWPZ, with similar sowing times and seeding rate. For the North Eastern Plains Zone, the recommended variety is NEPZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-10 to 2022-11-25 and late sowing time from 2022-11-25 to 2022-12-15. The seeding rate is also 100 kg per hectare. For the Central Zone, the recommended variety is CZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-10 to 2022-11-30 and late sowing time from 2022-12-01 to 2022-12-15. The seeding rate is 100 kg per hectare. For the Peninsular Zone, the recommended variety is PZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-01 to 2022-11-25 and late sowing time from 2022-11-25 to 2022-12-10. The seeding rate is 100 kg per hectare. For the Southern Hills Zone, the recommended variety is SHZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-15 to 2022-11-30 and late sowing time from 2022-12-01 to 2022-12-15. The seeding rate is 100 kg per hectare.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: Wheat requires loamy soil that is well-drained and rich in organic matter. It is advisable to avoid sandy soil for wheat cultivation.

growth, wilting', 'pest_control': [{'@type': 'PesticideList', 'name': 'Chlorpyrifos', 'quantity': '2.5 ml/litre of water', 'stage': 'At the time of pest appearance'}]}, 'harvesting_guidelines_are': 'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: The weed management for wheat cultivation involves dealing with weeds such as Phalaris minor. Herbicides such as Clodinafop, Fenoxaprop-ethyl, Pinoxaden, Sulfosulfuron, Isoproturon, and Pendimethalin are used at different stages of growth. The herbicides are applied post-emergence 30-35 DAS and pre-emergence 1-3 DAS.

ground_truth: The diseases that affect wheat include Rust, Smut, and Blight, which can be identified by symptoms such as yellowing of leaves, stunted growth, and black/brown spots on leaves. The disease can be controlled by using Propiconazole at the quantity of 1 ml/litre of water at the time of disease appearance.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: Wheat requires loamy soil that is well-drained and rich in organic matter. Sandy soil should be avoided.

For the North Western Plains Zone, the requirements are NPK in the quantity of 150:60:40 kg per hectare at the time of sowing. For the North Eastern Plains Zone, the requirements are NPK in the quantity of 150:60:40 kg per hectare at the time of sowing. For the Central Zone, the requirements are NPK in the quantity of 120:60:40 kg per hectare at the time of sowing. For the Peninsular Zone, the requirements are NPK in the quantity of 120:60:40 kg per hectare at the time of sowing. For the Southern Hills Zone, the requirements are NPK in the quantity of 120:60:40 kg per hectare at the time of sowing.

Jointing Stage (65 DAS), Booting Stage (85 DAS), Milking Stage (105 DAS), Dough Stage (120 DAS)'}, 'needs_disease_treatements': {'@type': 'DiseaseTreatements', 'disease_name': 'Rust, Smut, Blight', growth, wilting', 'pest_control': [{'@type': 'PesticideList', 'name': 'Chlorpyrifos', 'quantity': '2.5 ml/litre of water', 'stage': 'At the time of pest appearance'}]}, 'harvesting_guidelines_are': 'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: For pests such as Aphids, Termites, Cutworms, which cause symptoms like yellowing of leaves, stunted growth, and wilting, the pesticide Chlorpyrifos is recommended. It should be applied at a quantity of 2.5 ml per litre of water at the time of pest appearance.

ground_truth: The diseases that affect wheat include Rust, Smut, and Blight, which can be identified by symptoms such as yellowing of leaves, stunted growth, and black/brown spots on leaves. The disease can be controlled by using Propiconazole at the quantity of 1 ml/litre of water at the time of disease appearance.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: The 'Happy seeder' is a tractor mounted machine that cuts and lifts paddy straw, sows wheat seed into the bare soil and deposits the straw over the sown area as mulch.

growth, wilting', 'pest_control': [{'@type': 'PesticideList', 'name': 'Chlorpyrifos', 'quantity': '2.5 ml/litre of water', 'stage': 'At the time of pest appearance'}]}, 'harvesting_guidelines_are': 'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: For pests such as Aphids, Termites, Cutworms, which cause symptoms like yellowing of leaves, stunted growth, and wilting, the pesticide Chlorpyrifos is recommended. It should be applied at a quantity of 2.5 ml per litre of water at the time of pest appearance.

ground_truth: The recommended irrigation schedule for wheat cultivation includes 5-6 irrigations at the following stages: CRI Stage (21 DAS), First Node (45 DAS), Jointing Stage (65 DAS), Booting Stage (85 DAS), Milking Stage (105 DAS), Dough Stage (120 DAS).

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: The 'Zero tillage' method in wheat farming is used for directly placing wheat seed and fertilizers at proper depth into the undisturbed soil after rice harvesting. This is done using a specially designed machine which creates narrow slits by the knife type furrow openers of zero tillage ferti-seed drill instead of shovel type furrow opener in conventional ferti-seed drill.

ground_truth: For the Northern Hills Zone, the recommended seed variety is NHZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-01 to 2022-11-20 and late sowing time from 2022-11-25 to 2022-12-15. The seeding rate is 100 kg per hectare. For the North Western Plains Zone, the recommended seed variety is NWPZ, with similar sowing times and seeding rate. For the North Eastern Plains Zone, the recommended seed variety is NEPZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-10 to 2022-11-25 and late sowing time from 2022-11-25 to 2022-12-15. The seeding rate is also 100 kg per hectare. For the Central Zone, the recommended seed variety is CZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-10 to 2022-11-30 and late sowing time from 2022-12-01 to 2022-12-15. The seeding rate is 100 kg per hectare. For the Peninsular Zone, the recommended seed variety is PZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-01 to 2022-11-25 and late sowing time from 2022-11-25 to 2022-12-10. The seeding rate is 100 kg per hectare. For the Southern Hills Zone, the recommended seed variety is SHZ, with early sowing time from 2022-11-15 to 2022-11-30 and late sowing time from 2022-12-01 to 2022-12-15. The seeding rate is 100 kg per hectare.

ground_truth: For the Northern Hills Zone, the early sowing time for wheat is from November 1, 2022, to November 20, 2022, and the late sowing time is from November 25, 2022, to December 15, 2022. The seeding rate is 100 kg per hectare. The fertilizer application requirements include the nutrient NPK in the quantity of 120:60:40 kg per hectare, applied at the time of sowing. For the North Western Plains Zone, the early sowing time is from November 1, 2022, to November 20, 2022, and the late sowing time is from November 25, 2022, to December 15, 2022. The seeding rate is also 100 kg per hectare. The fertilizer application requirements include the nutrient NPK in the quantity of 150:60:40 kg per hectare, applied at the time of sowing.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: Wheat can be cultivated in various regions of India considering seeding and fertilization needs. These regions include the Northern Hills Zone (Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand), North Western Plains Zone (Punjab, Haryana, Delhi, Rajasthan, western Uttar Pradesh, Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand), North Eastern Plains Zone (eastern Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand, Odisha, West Bengal, Assam, northeastern states), Central Zone (Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Gujarat, Kota and Udaipur divisions of Rajasthan, Jhansi division of Uttar Pradesh), Peninsular Zone (Maharashtra, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Goa, plains of Tamil Nadu), and Southern Hills Zone (hilly areas of Tamil Nadu and Kerala, Nilgiri and Palni hills of the southern plateau).

ground_truth: Wheat is grown in various regions in India. In the Northern Hills Zone, which includes Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, and Uttarakhand, the recommended seed variety is 'NHZ'. In the North Western Plains Zone, which includes Punjab, Haryana, Delhi, Rajasthan, western Uttar Pradesh, Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, and Uttarakhand, the recommended seed variety is 'NWPZ'. In the North Eastern Plains Zone, which includes eastern Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand, Odisha, West Bengal, Assam, and northeastern states, the recommended seed variety is 'NEPZ'. In the Central Zone, which includes Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Gujarat, Kota and Udaipur divisions of Rajasthan, and Jhansi division of Uttar Pradesh, the recommended seed variety is 'CZ'. In the Peninsular Zone, which includes Maharashtra, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Goa, and plains of Tamil Nadu, the recommended seed variety is 'PZ'. Lastly, in the Southern Hills Zone, which includes hilly areas of Tamil Nadu and Kerala, and Nilgiri and Palni hills of the southern plateau, the recommended seed variety is 'SHZ'.
