'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: The ideal temperature for wheat's germination is 10-15°C, for flowering it's 20-25°C, and for grain filling it's 15-20°C. Temperatures above 35°C have a negative effect on wheat.

ground_truth: Wheat can grow in various regions in India. In the Northern Hills Zone, which includes Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, and Uttarakhand, the recommended seed variety is 'NHZ'. In the North Western Plains Zone, which includes Punjab, Haryana, Delhi, Rajasthan, western Uttar Pradesh, Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, and Uttarakhand, the recommended seed variety is 'NWPZ'. In the North Eastern Plains Zone, which includes eastern Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand, Odisha, West Bengal, Assam, and northeastern states, the recommended seed variety is 'NEPZ'. In the Central Zone, which includes Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Gujarat, Kota and Udaipur divisions of Rajasthan, and Jhansi division of Uttar Pradesh, the recommended seed variety is 'CZ'. In the Peninsular Zone, which includes Maharashtra, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Goa, and plains of Tamil Nadu, the recommended seed variety is 'PZ'. Lastly, in the Southern Hills Zone, which includes hilly areas of Tamil Nadu and Kerala, and Nilgiri and Palni hills of the southern plateau, the recommended seed variety is 'SHZ'.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: 'Zero tillage' and 'Happy seeder' are two different types of wheat farming methods. 'Zero tillage' involves placing wheat seed and fertilizers directly at the proper depth into the undisturbed soil after rice harvesting. This is done using a specially designed machine that creates narrow slits by the knife type furrow openers of zero tillage ferti-seed drill instead of shovel type furrow opener in conventional ferti-seed drill. On the other hand, 'Happy seeder' is a tractor-mounted machine that cuts and lifts paddy straw, sows wheat seed into the bare soil, and deposits the straw over the sown area as mulch.

growth, wilting', 'pest_control': [{'@type': 'PesticideList', 'name': 'Chlorpyrifos', 'quantity': '2.5 ml/litre of water', 'stage': 'At the time of pest appearance'}]}, 'harvesting_guidelines_are': 'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: Wheat can be cultivated in various regions of India. These include the Northern Hills Zone (regions like Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand), North Western Plains Zone (regions like Punjab, Haryana, Delhi, Rajasthan, western Uttar Pradesh, Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand), North Eastern Plains Zone (regions like eastern Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand, Odisha, West Bengal, Assam, northeastern states), Central Zone (regions like Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Gujarat, Kota and Udaipur divisions of Rajasthan, Jhansi division of Uttar Pradesh), Peninsular Zone (regions like Maharashtra, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Goa, plains of Tamil Nadu), and Southern Hills Zone (regions like hilly areas of Tamil Nadu and Kerala, Nilgiri and Palni hills of the southern plateau).

ground_truth: Wheat is grown in various regions in India. In the Northern Hills Zone, which includes Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, and Uttarakhand, the recommended seed variety is 'NHZ'. In the North Western Plains Zone, which includes Punjab, Haryana, Delhi, Rajasthan, western Uttar Pradesh, Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, and Uttarakhand, the recommended seed variety is 'NWPZ'. In the North Eastern Plains Zone, which includes eastern Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand, Odisha, West Bengal, Assam, and northeastern states, the recommended seed variety is 'NEPZ'. In the Central Zone, which includes Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Gujarat, Kota and Udaipur divisions of Rajasthan, and Jhansi division of Uttar Pradesh, the recommended seed variety is 'CZ'. In the Peninsular Zone, which includes Maharashtra, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Goa, and plains of Tamil Nadu, the recommended seed variety is 'PZ'. Lastly, in the Southern Hills Zone, which includes hilly areas of Tamil Nadu and Kerala, and Nilgiri and Palni hills of the southern plateau, the recommended seed variety is 'SHZ'.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: For the North Western Plains Zone, the suggested seed types are KRL 19, PBW 502, PBW 527, PDW 291, PBW 550, HD 2967, PDW 314, WHD 943, DPW 621-50. The early sowing time is from 1st November to 20th November and the late sowing time is from 25th November to 30th November. For the North Eastern Plains Zone, the suggested seed types are KRL 19, PBW 343, PBW 443, HD 2733, MACS 6145, HD 2824, HD 2888, K 307, DBW 17, Raj 4120, CBW 38, HD 2967, DBW 39, MACS 6222, KRL 210, KRL 213, K 9162, K 7903, K 9533, DBW 252, DBW 187, HD 3086, HPBW 2/(+Fe/Zn), PBW 550, PBW 550 Unnat. The early sowing time is from 10th November to 25th November and the late sowing time is from 25th November to 30th November.

ground_truth: Wheat farming is suitable in various regions of India. These include the Northern Hills Zone (Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand), North Western Plains Zone (Punjab, Haryana, Delhi, Rajasthan, western Uttar Pradesh, Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand), North Eastern Plains Zone (eastern Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand, Odisha, West Bengal, Assam, northeastern states), Central Zone (Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Gujarat, Kota and Udaipur divisions of Rajasthan, Jhansi division of Uttar Pradesh), Peninsular Zone (Maharashtra, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Goa, plains of Tamil Nadu), and Southern Hills Zone (hilly areas of Tamil Nadu and Kerala, Nilgiri and Palni hills of the southern plateau). The seed recommendations vary by zone, with variety names such as NHZ, NWPZ, NEPZ, CZ, PZ, and SHZ suggested for the respective zones.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: Wheat needs 5-6 irrigations between Crown root initiation and flowering.

If there is less moisture in the field, then irrigate the field before sowing (paleva) and prepare the field by running harrow/cultivator if there is suitable moisture.', 'with_soil_moisture': 'If there is less moisture in the field, then irrigate the field before sowing (paleva) and prepare the field by running harrow/cultivator if there is suitable moisture.'}, 'seed_germination_test_requirements_are': 'Seed germination test should be conducted to check seed germination status of seed. To ensure optimum plant population and thereby good yield, minimum 85% germination is essential.', 'has_seed_fungicide_requirements': {'@type': 'Fungicide', 'name': 'Carboxin, Carbendazim, Tebuconazole, Trichoderma viride', 'quantity': 'Carboxin (75 WP @ 2.5 gm/kg seed) or Carbendazim (50 WP @ 2.5 gm/kg seed) or Tebuconazole (2DS @ 1.25 gm/kg seed) or a combination of a reduced dosage ground_truth: The NPK requirement for wheat in the Northern Hills Zone is 120:60:40 kg per hectare, while in the Peninsular Zone it is also 120:60:40 kg per hectare.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: For the North Eastern Plains Zone, the recommended wheat varieties include KRL 19, PBW 343, PBW 443, HD 2733, MACS 6145, HD 2824, HD 2888, K 307, DBW 17, Raj 4120, CBW 38, HD 2967, DBW 39, MACS 6222, KRL 210, KRL 213, K 9162, K 7903, K 9533, DBW 252, DBW 187, HD 3086, HPBW 2/(+Fe/Zn), PBW 550, PBW 550 Unnat. The early sowing time is from 10th November to 25th November and the late sowing time is from 25th November to 30th November. The seeding rate is 100 kg/ha. The fertilizer application requirement is Nitrogen at 120 kg/ha at sowing. For the Central Zone, the recommended wheat varieties include KRL 19, GW 1139, GW 322, HI 1500, HI 8627, HI 1531, GW 366, HI 8498, HI 1544, MACS 2971, MPO 1215, MP 3288, HI 8713, HI 8737, DBW 110, MPO 1106, HI 1479, DDW 47, DBW 110. The early sowing time is from 10th November to 30th November and the late sowing time is from 1st December to 15th December. The seeding rate is 100 kg/ha. The fertilizer application requirement is Nitrogen at 120 kg/ha at sowing.

'stage': 'At the time of disease appearance'}]}, 'needs_pest_treatements': {'@type': 'PestTreatements', 'pest_name': 'Aphids, Termites, Cutworms', 'pest_symptoms': 'Yellowing of leaves, stunted growth, wilting', 'pest_control': [{'@type': 'PesticideList', 'name': 'Chlorpyrifos', 'quantity': '2.5 ml/litre of water', 'stage': 'At the time of pest appearance'}]}, 'harvesting_guidelines_are': 'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: For the North Eastern Plains Zone, the recommended wheat varieties include KRL 19, PBW 343, PBW 443, HD 2733, MACS 6145, HD 2824, HD 2888, K 307, DBW 17, Raj 4120, CBW 38, HD 2967, DBW 39, MACS 6222, KRL 210, KRL 213, K 9162, K 7903, K 9533, DBW 252, DBW 187, HD 3086, HPBW 2/(+Fe/Zn), PBW 550, PBW 550 Unnat. The early sowing time is from 10th November to 25th November and late sowing time is from 25th November to 30th November. The seeding rate is 100 kg/ha. The fertilizer application requirement is Nitrogen at 120 kg/ha at sowing. For the Central Zone, the recommended wheat varieties include KRL 19, GW 1139, GW 322, HI 1500, HI 8627, HI 1531, GW 366, HI 8498, HI 1544, MACS 2971, MPO 1215, MP 3288, HI 8713, HI 8737, DBW 110, MPO 1106, HI 1479, DDW 47, DBW 110. The early sowing time is from 10th November to 30th November and late sowing time is from 1st December to 15th December. The seeding rate is 100 kg/ha. The fertilizer application requirement is Nitrogen at 120 kg/ha at sowing.

ground_truth: Wheat farming is suitable in various regions of India. In the Northern Hills Zone, which includes Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, and Uttarakhand, the recommended seed variety is NHZ. In the North Western Plains Zone, which includes Punjab, Haryana, Delhi, Rajasthan, western Uttar Pradesh, Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, and Uttarakhand, the recommended seed variety is NWPZ. In the North Eastern Plains Zone, which includes eastern Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand, Odisha, West Bengal, Assam, and northeastern states, the recommended seed variety is NEPZ. In the Central Zone, which includes Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Gujarat, Kota and Udaipur divisions of Rajasthan, and Jhansi division of Uttar Pradesh, the recommended seed variety is CZ. In the Peninsular Zone, which includes Maharashtra, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Goa, and plains of Tamil Nadu, the recommended seed variety is PZ. Finally, in the Southern Hills Zone, which includes hilly areas of Tamil Nadu and Kerala, Nilgiri and Palni hills of the southern plateau, the recommended seed variety is SHZ.

Jointing Stage (65 DAS), Booting Stage (85 DAS), Milking Stage (105 DAS), Dough Stage (120 DAS)'}, 'needs_disease_treatements': {'@type': 'DiseaseTreatements', 'disease_name': 'Rust, Smut, Blight', 'disease_symptoms': 'Yellowing of leaves, stunted growth, black/brown spots on leaves', 'disease_control': [{'@type': 'HerbicideList', 'name': 'Propiconazole', 'quantity': '1 ml/litre of water', 'stage': 'At the time of disease appearance'}]}, 'needs_pest_treatements': {'@type': 'PestTreatements', 'pest_name': 'Aphids, Termites, Cutworms', 'pest_symptoms': 'Yellowing of leaves, stunted growth, wilting', 'pest_control': [{'@type': 'PesticideList', 'name': 'Chlorpyrifos', 'quantity': '2.5 ml/litre of water', 'stage': 'At the time of pest appearance'}]}, 'harvesting_guidelines_are': 'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: The pests that impact wheat and can cause symptoms such as yellowing of leaves and stunted growth are Aphids, Termites, and Cutworms. The treatment for these pests includes using a pesticide like Chlorpyrifos in a quantity of 2.5 ml/litre of water at the time of pest appearance.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: For wheat fertilization across zones and tillage methods, the nutrient used is Nitrogen and the stage of application is at sowing. The quantity varies depending on the zone. For the North Western Plains Zone, North Eastern Plains Zone, and Central Zone, the quantity is 120 kg/ha. For the Peninsular Zone and Southern Hills Zone, the quantity is not specified in the context.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: Wheat cultivation specifics vary by zone and method. For the North Western Plains Zone, varieties like KRL 19, PBW 502, PBW 527, PDW 291, PBW 550, HD 2967, PDW 314, WHD 943, DPW 621-50 are recommended, with sowing times between 1st and 20th November for early sowing and 25th to 30th November for late sowing. The seeding rate is 100 kg/ha and Nitrogen fertilizer is applied at 120 kg/ha at sowing. For the North Eastern Plains Zone, varieties like KRL 19, PBW 343, PBW 443, HD 2733, MACS 6145, HD 2824, HD 2888, K 307, DBW 17, Raj 4120, CBW 38, HD 2967, DBW 39, MACS 6222, KRL 210, KRL 213, K 9162, K 7903, K 9533, DBW 252, DBW 187, HD 3086, HPBW 2/(+Fe/Zn), PBW 550, PBW 550 Unnat are recommended, with sowing times between 10th and 25th November for early sowing and 25th to 30th November for late sowing. The seeding rate is 100 kg/ha and Nitrogen fertilizer is applied at 120 kg/ha at sowing. For the Central Zone, varieties like KRL 19, GW 1139, GW 322, HI 1500, HI 8627, HI 1531, GW 366, HI 8498, HI 1544, MACS 2971, MPO 1215, MP 3288, HI 8713, HI 8737, DBW 110, MPO 1106, HI 1479, DDW 47, DBW 110 are recommended, with sowing times between 10th and 30th November for early sowing and 1st to 15th December for late sowing. The seeding rate is 100 kg/ha and Nitrogen fertilizer is applied at 120 kg/ha at sowing. For the Peninsular Zone, varieties like GW 322, HD 2781, GW 1189, NIDW 295, Raj 4037, DDK 1025, NIAW 917, AKDW 2997-16, DDK 1029, HI 8663, AKAW 3722, MACS 2971, PBW 596, UAS 415, HD 2987, NIAW 1415, UAS 428, NIAW 301, MACS 3125, DBW 168, DBW 93 are recommended, with sowing times between 1st and 25th November for early sowing and 25th to 10th December for late sowing. The seeding rate is 100 kg/ha and Nitrogen fertilizer is applied at 120 kg/ha at sowing. For the Northern Hills Zone, varieties like VL 829, HPW 251, VL 907, VL 804, HPW 155, HS 375, SKW 196, VL 832, TL 2942, HS 507, HPW 349, HS 420, VL 892, HS 490 are recommended, with sowing times between 25th October and 1st November for early sowing and 25th to 30th November for late sowing. The seeding rate is 100 kg/ha and Nitrogen fertilizer is applied at 120 kg/ha at sowing. For the Southern Hills Zone, varieties like HW 2044, HW 5216 are recommended, with sowing times between 15th and 30th November. The seeding rate is 100 kg/ha and Nitrogen fertilizer is applied at 120 kg/ha at sowing. In terms of methods, Zero tillage involves directly placing wheat seed and fertilizers at proper depth into the undisturbed soil after rice harvesting using a specially designed machine. Happy seeder is a tractor mounted machine that cuts and lifts paddy straw, sows wheat seed into the bare soil and deposits the straw over the sown area as mulch.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: Wheat cultivation varies across different Indian zones and methods. For traditional methods, wheat is grown in various zones including the Northern Hills Zone, North Western Plains Zone, North Eastern Plains Zone, Central Zone, Peninsular Zone, and Southern Hills Zone. Each zone has specific seed recommendations, sowing times, seeding rates, and fertilizer application requirements. For example, in the Northern Hills Zone, the recommended variety is 'NHZ' with a seeding rate of 100 kg per hectare and a fertilizer requirement of 'NPK' at '120:60:40 kg per hectare'. The sowing time varies from early November to mid-December. In the zero tillage method, wheat seed and fertilizers are directly placed at proper depth into the undisturbed soil after rice harvesting using a specially designed machine. This method is used in the North Western Plains Zone and North Eastern Plains Zone with specific seed recommendations, sowing times, seeding rates, and fertilizer application requirements. For instance, in the North Western Plains Zone, the recommended varieties include 'KRL 19', 'PBW 502', 'PBW 527', 'PDW 291', 'PBW 550', 'HD 2967', 'PDW 314', 'WHD 943', 'DPW 621-50' with a seeding rate of 100 kg per hectare and a fertilizer requirement of 'Nitrogen' at '120 kg/ha'. The sowing time is from early November to late November.

ground_truth: The 'Happy seeder' is a tractor mounted machine that cuts and lifts paddy straw, sows wheat seed into the bare soil and deposits the straw over the sown area as mulch.

question: What's the NPK nutrient breakdown and application stages for wheat in Indian zones, and its alignment with nitrogen recommendations for different wheat types?

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: The NPK nutrient breakdown for wheat in different Indian zones varies. For the Northern Hills Zone, North Western Plains Zone, Central Zone, and Southern Hills Zone, the NPK nutrient breakdown is 120:60:40 kg per hectare. For the North Eastern Plains Zone and Peninsular Zone, the NPK nutrient breakdown is 150:60:40 kg per hectare. The fertilizer is applied at the time of sowing in all zones. The nitrogen recommendations for different wheat types are not specified in the context.

growth, wilting', 'pest_control': [{'@type': 'PesticideList', 'name': 'Chlorpyrifos', 'quantity': '2.5 ml/litre of water', 'stage': 'At the time of pest appearance'}]}, 'harvesting_guidelines_are': 'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: Wheat farming involves several processes including land preparation, sowing, irrigation, weed management, disease and pest treatment, harvesting, and storage. The land is prepared by placing wheat seed and fertilizers at proper depth into the undisturbed soil after rice harvesting using a specially designed machine. The seeds are sown at a specific spacing and depth. The crop requires 5-6 irrigations at different stages of growth. Weed management is done using various herbicides. Diseases and pests are treated using specific chemicals. The crop is harvested when the moisture level of grain is 25% and stored in bins and silos made of GI sheets. The entire process of wheat farming has a significant impact on food production as wheat is a staple food in many countries.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth:
Wheat cultivation varies based on the growing zone and tillage method. For the 'Zero tillage' method, wheat seed and fertilizers are directly placed at proper depth into the undisturbed soil after rice harvesting using a specially designed machine. The 'Happy seeder' method involves a tractor-mounted machine that cuts and lifts paddy straw, sows wheat seed into the bare soil, and deposits the straw over the sown area as mulch. 

In the 'North Western Plains Zone', varieties like 'KRL 19', 'PBW 502', 'PBW 527', 'PDW 291', 'PBW 550', 'HD 2967', 'PDW 314', 'WHD 943', 'DPW 621-50' are recommended, with sowing times between 1st and 20th November for early sowing and 25th to 30th November for late sowing. 

In the 'North Eastern Plains Zone', varieties like 'KRL 19', 'PBW 343', 'PBW 443', 'HD 2733', 'MACS 6145', 'HD 2824', 'HD 2888', 'K 307', 'DBW 17', 'Raj 4120', 'CBW 38', 'HD 2967', 'DBW 39', 'MACS 6222', 'KRL 210', 'KRL 213', 'K 9162', 'K 7903', 'K 9533', 'DBW 252', 'DBW 187', 'HD 3086', 'HPBW 2/(+Fe/Zn)', 'PBW 550', 'PBW 550 Unnat' are recommended, with sowing times between 10th and 25th November for early sowing and 25th to 30th November for late sowing. 

In the 'Central Zone', varieties like 'KRL 19', 'GW 1139', 'GW 322', 'HI 1500', 'HI 8627', 'HI 1531', 'GW 366', 'HI 8498', 'HI 1544', 'MACS 2971', 'MPO 1215', 'MP 3288', 'HI 8713', 'HI 8737', 'DBW 110', 'MPO 1106', 'HI 1479', 'DDW 47', 'DBW 110' are recommended, with sowing times between 10th and 30th November for early sowing and 1st to 15th December for late sowing. 

In the 'Peninsular Zone', varieties like 'GW 322', 'HD 2781', 'GW 1189', 'NIDW 295', 'Raj 4037', 'DDK 1025', 'NIAW 917', 'AKDW 2997-16', 'DDK 1029', 'HI 8663', 'AKAW 3722', 'MACS 2971', 'PBW 596', 'UAS 415', 'HD 2987', 'NIAW 1415', 'UAS 428', 'NIAW 301', 'MACS 3125', 'DBW 168', 'DBW 93' are recommended, with sowing times between 1st and 25th November for early sowing and 25th November to 10th December for late sowing. 

In the 'Northern Hills Zone', varieties like 'VL 829', 'HPW 251', 'VL 907', 'VL 804', 'HPW 155', 'HS 375', 'SKW 196', 'VL 832', 'TL 2942', 'HS 507', 'HPW 349', 'HS 420', 'VL 892', 'HS 490' are recommended, with sowing times between 25th October and 1st November for early sowing and 25th to 30th November for late sowing. 

In the 'Southern Hills Zone', varieties like 'HW 2044', 'HW 5216' are recommended, with sowing times between 15th and 30th November.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth:
Wheat cultivation in India's zones requires specific seed varieties, sowing times, seeding rates, and fertilizer application requirements for each zone. For example, in the North Western Plains Zone, varieties like KRL 19, PBW 502, and PBW 527 are recommended, with early sowing time from 1st to 20th November and late sowing time from 25th to 30th November. The seeding rate is 100 kg/ha and Nitrogen fertilizer should be applied at 120 kg/ha at sowing. Similar guidelines are provided for other zones like North Eastern Plains Zone, Central Zone, Peninsular Zone, Northern Hills Zone, and Southern Hills Zone. 

In terms of land preparation, two methods are mentioned: traditional and zero tillage. The traditional method involves leveling the field, ploughing, harrowing, and planking. If there is less moisture in the field, it should be irrigated before sowing and prepared by running a harrow or cultivator if there is suitable moisture. 

The zero tillage method involves directly placing wheat seed and fertilizers at proper depth into the undisturbed soil after rice harvesting using a specially designed machine. This machine creates narrow slits by the knife type furrow openers of zero tillage ferti-seed drill instead of shovel type furrow opener in conventional ferti-seed drill. 

Other requirements include temperature requirements for germination, flowering, and grain filling, soil requirements, seed fungicide requirements, seed sowing spacing, weed management, irrigation schedule, disease and pest treatments, harvesting guidelines, and storage guidelines.

ground_truth: In zero tillage, wheat seed and fertilizers are directly placed at proper depth into the undisturbed soil after rice harvesting using a specially designed machine. This machine creates narrow slits by the knife type furrow openers of zero tillage ferti-seed drill. In contrast, traditional methods use a shovel type furrow opener in conventional ferti-seed drill.

growth, wilting', 'pest_control': [{'@type': 'PesticideList', 'name': 'Chlorpyrifos', 'quantity': '2.5 ml/litre of water', 'stage': 'At the time of pest appearance'}]}, 'harvesting_guidelines_are': 'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: Wheat cultivation zones in India include the North Western Plains Zone, North Eastern Plains Zone, Central Zone, Peninsular Zone, Northern Hills Zone, and Southern Hills Zone. In the North Western Plains Zone, which includes regions like Punjab, Haryana, Delhi, Rajasthan, and others, recommended seed varieties include KRL 19, PBW 502, PBW 527, and others. The early sowing time is from 1st November to 20th November, and the seeding rate is 100 kg/ha. Nitrogen fertilizer is recommended at a quantity of 120 kg/ha at sowing. Similar information is available for other zones, with different seed varieties, sowing times, seeding rates, and fertilizer needs. For instance, in the North Eastern Plains Zone, seed varieties like KRL 19, PBW 343, PBW 443, and others are recommended, with a sowing time from 10th November to 25th November, and the same seeding rate and fertilizer needs as the North Western Plains Zone.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: Wheat is a significant crop used for food production. It is cultivated in various growing zones, each with specific seed recommendations, sowing times, seeding rates, and fertilizer application requirements. The cultivation of wheat requires specific temperature and soil requirements, and the land must be prepared according to certain instructions. The seeds must be treated with a specific fungicide, and the sowing must follow a certain spacing method. Weed management is also crucial in wheat cultivation, and a specific irrigation schedule must be followed. The crop may be susceptible to certain diseases and pests, for which treatments are available. Finally, there are specific guidelines for harvesting and storing wheat to ensure the quality of the produce for food production.

ground_truth: For disease management in wheat farming, the diseases that need to be treated include Yellow Rust, Brown or leaf rust, Loose Smut, Karnal Bunt, Powdery Mildew, and Flag Smut. The control measures include using herbicides like Propiconazole, Tebuconazole, and Carboxin. The quantity and stage of application vary. For pest management, the pests that need to be controlled include Termite, Aphids, and Pink Stem Borer. The control measures include using pesticides like Thiamethoxam, Fipronil, Imidacloprid, and Quinalphos. The quantity and stage of application vary.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: The pest control protocol for wheat cultivation involves the use of Chlorpyrifos. It should be applied at a quantity of 2.5 ml per litre of water at the time of pest appearance. The pests that can affect wheat include Aphids, Termites, and Cutworms, and their symptoms include yellowing of leaves, stunted growth, and wilting.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: nan

'stage': 'pre-emergence 1-3 DAS'}]}, 'needs_irrigation_schedule': {'@type': 'IrrigationRequirement', 'quantity': '5-6 irrigations', 'stage_of_application': 'CRI Stage (21 DAS), First Node (45 DAS), Jointing Stage (65 DAS), Booting Stage (85 DAS), Milking Stage (105 DAS), Dough Stage (120 DAS)'}, 'needs_disease_treatements': {'@type': 'DiseaseTreatements', 'disease_name': 'Rust, Smut, Blight', 'disease_symptoms': 'Yellowing of leaves, stunted growth, black/brown spots on leaves', 'disease_control': [{'@type': 'HerbicideList', 'name': 'Propiconazole', 'quantity': '1 ml/litre of water', 'stage': 'At the time of disease appearance'}]}, 'needs_pest_treatements': {'@type': 'PestTreatements', 'pest_name': 'Aphids, Termites, Cutworms', 'pest_symptoms': 'Yellowing of leaves, stunted growth, wilting', 'pest_control': [{'@type': 'PesticideList', 'name': 'Chlorpyrifos', 'quantity': '2.5 ml/litre of water', 'stage': 'At the time of pest appearance'}]}, 'harvesting_guidelines_are': 'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: For traditional and zero tillage methods of wheat cultivation, the requirements vary across different zones. In the North Western Plains Zone, varieties like KRL 19, PBW 502, PBW 527, PDW 291, PBW 550, HD 2967, PDW 314, WHD 943, DPW 621-50 are recommended with a seeding rate of 100 kg/ha and Nitrogen fertilizer application of 120 kg/ha at sowing. In the North Eastern Plains Zone, varieties like KRL 19, PBW 343, PBW 443, HD 2733, MACS 6145, HD 2824, HD 2888, K 307, DBW 17, Raj 4120, CBW 38, HD 2967, DBW 39, MACS 6222, KRL 210, KRL 213, K 9162, K 7903, K 9533, DBW 252, DBW 187, HD 3086, HPBW 2/(+Fe/Zn), PBW 550, PBW 550 Unnat are recommended with a seeding rate of 100 kg/ha and Nitrogen fertilizer application of 120 kg/ha at sowing. In the Central Zone, varieties like KRL 19, GW 1139, GW 322, HI 1500, HI 8627, HI 1531, GW 366, HI 8498, HI 1544, MACS 2971, MPO 1215, MP 3288, HI 8713, HI 8737, DBW 110, MPO 1106, HI 1479, DDW 47, DBW 110 are recommended with a seeding rate of 100 kg/ha and Nitrogen fertilizer application of 120 kg/ha at sowing. In the Peninsular Zone, varieties like GW 322, HD 2781, GW 1189, NIDW 295, Raj 4037, DDK 1025, NIAW 917, AKDW 2997-16, DDK 1029, HI 8663, AKAW 3722, MACS 2971, PBW 596, UAS 415, HD 2987, NIAW 1415, UAS 428, NIAW 301, MACS 3125, DBW 168, DBW 93 are recommended with a seeding rate of 100 kg/ha and Nitrogen fertilizer application of 120 kg/ha at sowing. In the Northern Hills Zone, varieties like VL 829, HPW 251, VL 907, VL 804, HPW 155, HS 375, SKW 196, VL 832, TL 2942, HS 507, HPW 349, HS 420, VL 892, HS 490 are recommended with a seeding rate of 100 kg/ha and Nitrogen fertilizer application of 120 kg/ha at sowing. In the Southern Hills Zone, varieties like HW 2044, HW 5216 are recommended with a seeding rate of 100 kg/ha and Nitrogen fertilizer application of 120 kg/ha at sowing.

ground_truth:
Wheat cultivation varies based on the growing zone and tillage method. For the 'Zero tillage' method, wheat seed and fertilizers are directly placed at proper depth into the undisturbed soil after rice harvesting using a specially designed machine. The 'Happy seeder' method involves a tractor-mounted machine that cuts and lifts paddy straw, sows wheat seed into the bare soil, and deposits the straw over the sown area as mulch. 

In the 'North Western Plains Zone', varieties like 'KRL 19', 'PBW 502', 'PBW 527', 'PDW 291', 'PBW 550', 'HD 2967', 'PDW 314', 'WHD 943', 'DPW 621-50' are recommended, with sowing times between 1st and 30th November. The 'North Eastern Plains Zone' recommends varieties like 'KRL 19', 'PBW 343', 'PBW 443', 'HD 2733', 'MACS 6145', 'HD 2824', 'HD 2888', 'K 307', 'DBW 17', 'Raj 4120', 'CBW 38', 'HD 2967', 'DBW 39', 'MACS 6222', 'KRL 210', 'KRL 213', 'K 9162', 'K 7903', 'K 9533', 'DBW 252', 'DBW 187', 'HD 3086', 'HPBW 2/(+Fe/Zn)', 'PBW 550', 'PBW 550 Unnat' with sowing times between 10th and 30th November. 

The 'Central Zone' recommends varieties like 'KRL 19', 'GW 1139', 'GW 322', 'HI 1500', 'HI 8627', 'HI 1531', 'GW 366', 'HI 8498', 'HI 1544', 'MACS 2971', 'MPO 1215', 'MP 3288', 'HI 8713', 'HI 8737', 'DBW 110', 'MPO 1106', 'HI 1479', 'DDW 47', 'DBW 110' with sowing times between 10th November and 15th December. 

The 'Peninsular Zone' recommends varieties like 'GW 322', 'HD 2781', 'GW 1189', 'NIDW 295', 'Raj 4037', 'DDK 1025', 'NIAW 917', 'AKDW 2997-16', 'DDK 1029', 'HI 8663', 'AKAW 3722', 'MACS 2971', 'PBW 596', 'UAS 415', 'HD 2987', 'NIAW 1415', 'UAS 428', 'NIAW 301', 'MACS 3125', 'DBW 168', 'DBW 93' with sowing times between 1st and 10th December. 

The 'Northern Hills Zone' recommends varieties like 'VL 829', 'HPW 251', 'VL 907', 'VL 804', 'HPW 155', 'HS 375', 'SKW 196', 'VL 832', 'TL 2942', 'HS 507', 'HPW 349', 'HS 420', 'VL 892', 'HS 490' with sowing times between 25th October and 30th November. 

The 'Southern Hills Zone' recommends varieties like 'HW 2044', 'HW 5216' with sowing times between 15th and 30th November. 

For all zones, the seeding rate is 100 kg/ha and Nitrogen fertilizer is applied at 120 kg/ha at sowing.

ground_truth: Wheat farming requires a soil type that is loamy, with good structure and moderate water holding capacity. It should avoid very porous and excessively drained soils, as well as heavy soil with poor structure and poor drainage. The soil should be rich in organic matter and have a moderate water holding capacity. In terms of climate, the temperature for germination should be 10-15°C, for flowering it should be 20-25°C, and for grain filling it should be 15-20°C. Temperatures above 35°C can have a negative effect on the crop. The nutrient needs for wheat farming include Nitrogen, with a quantity of 120 kg/ha, applied at the time of sowing.

growth, wilting', 'pest_control': [{'@type': 'PesticideList', 'name': 'Chlorpyrifos', 'quantity': '2.5 ml/litre of water', 'stage': 'At the time of pest appearance'}]}, 'harvesting_guidelines_are': 'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: Wheat plays a significant role in food production as it is a staple food in many regions. Its cultivation and management needs include specific temperature requirements for germination, flowering, and grain filling. It requires loamy soil that is well-drained and rich in organic matter. The land preparation involves placing wheat seed and fertilizers at proper depth into the undisturbed soil after rice harvesting. The seed requires fungicide treatment and specific sowing spacing. Weed management is crucial and involves the use of specific herbicides. The crop requires 5-6 irrigations at specific stages. Disease and pest treatments are necessary to maintain the health of the crop. Harvesting should be done when the moisture level of grain is 25% and storage should be in bins and silos made of GI sheets.
