growth, wilting', 'pest_control': [{'@type': 'PesticideList', 'name': 'Chlorpyrifos', 'quantity': '2.5 ml/litre of water', 'stage': 'At the time of pest appearance'}]}, 'harvesting_guidelines_are': 'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: The suggested herbicides for Phalaris minor in wheat farming are Clodinafop (60 gm a.i. /ha), Fenoxaprop-ethyl (100-120 gm a.i. /ha), Pinoxaden (40-50 gm a.i. /ha), Sulfosulfuron (25 gm a.i. /ha), Isoproturon (1000 gm a.i. /ha), and Pendimethalin (1000-1500 gm a.i. /ha). All these herbicides should be applied post-emergence 30-35 DAS (Days After Sowing).

ground_truth: The advised herbicides for managing Phalaris minor in wheat are Clodinafop (60 gm a.i. /ha), Fenoxaprop-ethyl (100-120 gm a.i. /ha), Pinoxaden (40-50 gm a.i. /ha), Sulfosulfuron (25 gm a.i. /ha), Isoproturon (1000 gm a.i. /ha), and Pendimethalin (1000-1500 gm a.i. /ha). These should be applied post-emergence 30-35 DAS. The fertilizer requirement for wheat is Nitrogen at a quantity of 120 kg/ha, applied at sowing. The sowing times and growing zones vary depending on the specific variety of wheat and the region.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. ground_truth: The pest control protocol for wheat involves the use of pesticides such as Chlorpyrifos, which should be applied at the time of pest appearance. The pests that can affect wheat include Aphids, Termites, and Cutworms, and their symptoms include yellowing of leaves, stunted growth, and wilting.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth:
India's wheat zones include the North Western Plains Zone, North Eastern Plains Zone, Central Zone, Peninsular Zone, Northern Hills Zone, and Southern Hills Zone. 

In the North Western Plains Zone, regions include Punjab, Haryana, Delhi, Rajasthan, western Uttar Pradesh, Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, and Uttarakhand. Seed varieties recommended for this zone include KRL 19, PBW 502, PBW 527, PDW 291, PBW 550, HD 2967, PDW 314, WHD 943, DPW 621-50. The early sowing time is from 1st November to 20th November and the late sowing time is from 25th November to 30th November. The seeding rate is 100 kg/ha and the fertilizer requirement is 120 kg/ha of Nitrogen at sowing.

In the North Eastern Plains Zone, regions include eastern Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand, Odisha, West Bengal, Assam, northeastern states. Seed varieties recommended for this zone include KRL 19, PBW 343, PBW 443, HD 2733, MACS 6145, HD 2824, HD 2888, K 307, DBW 17, Raj 4120, CBW 38, HD 2967, DBW 39, MACS 6222, KRL 210, KRL 213, K 9162, K 7903, K 9533, DBW 252, DBW 187, HD 3086, HPBW 2/(+Fe/Zn), PBW 550, PBW 550 Unnat. The early sowing time is from 10th November to 25th November and the late sowing time is from 25th November to 30th November. The seeding rate is 100 kg/ha and the fertilizer requirement is 120 kg/ha of Nitrogen at sowing.

In the Central Zone, regions include Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Gujarat, Kota and Udaipur divisions of Rajasthan, Jhansi division of Uttar Pradesh. Seed varieties recommended for this zone include KRL 19, GW 1139, GW 322, HI 1500, HI 8627, HI 1531, GW 366, HI 8498, HI 1544, MACS 2971, MPO 1215, MP 3288, HI 8713, HI 8737, DBW 110, MPO 1106, HI 1479, DDW 47, DBW 110. The early sowing time is from 10th November to 30th November and the late sowing time is from 1st December to 15th December. The seeding rate is 100 kg/ha and the fertilizer requirement is 120 kg/ha of Nitrogen at sowing.

In the Peninsular Zone, regions include Maharashtra, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Goa, plains of Tamil Nadu. Seed varieties recommended for this zone include GW 322, HD 2781, GW 1189, NIDW 295, Raj 4037, DDK 1025, NIAW 917, AKDW 2997-16, DDK 1029, HI 8663, AKAW 3722, MACS 2971, PBW 596, UAS 415, HD 2987, NIAW 1415, UAS 428, NIAW 301, MACS 3125, DBW 168, DBW 93. The early sowing time is from 1st November to 25th November and the late sowing time is from 25th November to 10th December. The seeding rate is 100 kg/ha and the fertilizer requirement is 120 kg/ha of Nitrogen at sowing.

In the Northern Hills Zone, regions include western Himalayan regions of Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand, Sikkim, hills of West Bengal, northeastern states. Seed varieties recommended for this zone include VL 829, HPW 251, VL 907, VL 804, HPW 155, HS 375, SKW 196, VL 832, TL 2942, HS 507, HPW 349, HS 420, VL 892, HS 490. The early sowing time is from 25th October to 1st November and the late sowing time is from 25th November to 30th November. The seeding rate is 100 kg/ha and the fertilizer requirement is 120 kg/ha of Nitrogen at sowing.

In the Southern Hills Zone, regions include hilly areas of Tamil Nadu and Kerala, Nilgiri and Palni hills of the southern plateau. Seed varieties recommended for this zone include HW 2044, HW 5216. The early sowing time is from 15th November to 30th November. The seeding rate is 100 kg/ha and the fertilizer requirement is 120 kg/ha of Nitrogen at sowing.

For zero tillage, wheat seed and fertilizers are directly placed at proper depth into the undisturbed soil after rice harvesting using a specially designed machine which creates narrow slits by the knife type furrow openers of zero tillage ferti-seed drill instead of shovel type furrow opener in conventional ferti-seed drill.

ground_truth: In 'Zero tillage' method, wheat seed and fertilizers are directly placed at proper depth into the undisturbed soil after rice harvesting using a specially designed machine. This machine creates narrow slits by the knife type furrow openers of zero tillage ferti-seed drill. In contrast, traditional methods use a shovel type furrow opener in conventional ferti-seed drill.

question: What's needed for wheat cultivation in various zones using traditional and zero tillage methods?

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth:
For wheat cultivation in various zones using traditional and zero tillage methods, the following are needed: 

1. Suitable seed varieties for each zone. For example, in the North Western Plains Zone, varieties like KRL 19, PBW 502, PBW 527, PDW 291, PBW 550, HD 2967, PDW 314, WHD 943, DPW 621-50 are recommended. 

2. Proper sowing times. In the North Western Plains Zone, early sowing time is from 1st November to 20th November and late sowing time is from 25th November to 30th November. 

3. Adequate seeding rate. For all zones, the recommended seeding rate is 100 kg per hectare. 

4. Fertilizer application requirements. For example, in the North Western Plains Zone, Nitrogen is applied at the rate of 120 kg per hectare at sowing. 

5. Suitable temperature requirements for germination, flowering, and grain filling. The temperature for germination is 10-15°C, for flowering is 20-25°C, and for grain filling is 15-20°C. 

6. Suitable soil type. Loamy soil is preferred, and sandy soil should be avoided. The soil should be well-drained and rich in organic matter. 

7. Land preparation requirements. In zero tillage, wheat seed and fertilizers are directly placed at proper depth into the undisturbed soil after rice harvesting using a specially designed machine. 

8. Seed fungicide requirements. Carbendazim is used at the rate of 2 gm/kg of seeds. 

9. Seed sowing spacing. The sowing time is in winter, the value is 15-20 cm, and the depth is 3-4 cm. The method used is drilling. 

10. Weed management needs. Weeds like Phalaris minor are managed using herbicides like Clodinafop, Fenoxaprop-ethyl, Pinoxaden, Sulfosulfuron, Isoproturon, and Pendimethalin. 

11. Irrigation schedule. 5-6 irrigations are needed at stages like CRI Stage (21 DAS), First Node (45 DAS), Jointing Stage (65 DAS), Booting Stage (85 DAS), Milking Stage (105 DAS), Dough Stage (120 DAS). 

12. Disease treatments. Diseases like Rust, Smut, Blight are controlled using herbicides like Propiconazole. 

13. Pest treatments. Pests like Aphids, Termites, Cutworms are controlled using pesticides like Chlorpyrifos. 

14. Harvesting guidelines. The crop should be harvested when the moisture level of grain is 25%. 

15. Storage guidelines. The grains should be stored in bins and silos made of GI sheets, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos, and poly lined bags.

'When the moisture level of grain is 25% it is the proper time for manual harvesting. Generally, wheat is manually harvested but for quick harvesting, combine harvester should be used to avoid losses in grain yield due to shattering and lodging. Wheat should be harvested 4-5 days before it is dead ripe. Morning is the best time for harvesting. Mechanical harvesting through combine machine is done at places where uniform ripening of wheat happens. In case of manual harvesting, bundles are made and dried for 3-4 days and threshed by thresher. Before storage, grain should be dried by spreading on tarpaulin plastic sheets in bright sunlight to a moisture level below 12%.', 'storage_guidelines_are': 'For storage, use bins and silos made of GI sheets. Now a days, aluminium bins, Pusa bins, silos and poly lined bags are available for storage. Farmers can store wheat grains in their traditional storage as well. Improved storage structures of various capacities are now available. The air-tight bin can be used. It is so constructed that it does not allow entry of any outside insects and rodents and the insects present in the grain do not get favourable atmosphere to develop. For filling and using the metal bin, the following storage practices are recommended: Clean the bin thoroughly and do not allow the left-overs of the previously stored grains to remain in the bin. Inspect the covers to ensure that the gaskets are intact. Clean and sort the grains of all impurities. Broken kernels and other impurities lead to insect attraction and, hence, should be separated. Do not mix the new grains with old stock as the latter may be infested with insects. Never store infested grains, or grains with high moisture content. Dry the grains out in the sun, cool it and fill in the bin later in the evening. The moisture content of the grains should not be higher than 9 %. Fill-in the bin to full capacity and tight the lid properly. Do not open the bin for the first 30 days and thereafter open it fortnightly. The cover should be replaced immediately after use. Inspect the grains frequently.'}"]
ground_truth: Wheat cultivation involves several steps and considerations. The crop is used for food production and can be grown using traditional or zero tillage methods. In zero tillage, wheat seed and fertilizers are directly placed at proper depth into the undisturbed soil after rice harvesting using a specially designed machine. Happy seeder is another method where the machine cuts and lifts paddy straw, sows wheat seed into the bare soil and deposits the straw over the sown area as mulch. Wheat can be grown in various zones including North Western Plains Zone, North Eastern Plains Zone, Central Zone, Peninsular Zone, Northern Hills Zone, and Southern Hills Zone. Each zone has specific seed recommendations, sowing times, seeding rates, and fertilizer application requirements. The crop requires a temperature of 10-15°C for germination, 20-25°C for flowering, and 15-20°C for grain filling. The soil should be loamy, well-drained, and rich in organic matter. Land preparation involves leveling the field and ploughing. Seed germination test should be conducted to check seed germination status of seed. To ensure optimum plant population and thereby good yield, minimum 85% germination is essential. The crop requires weed management and irrigation schedule. Diseases and pests that affect the crop should be treated with appropriate measures. Harvesting should be done at proper maturity to minimize risk due to shattering, threshing etc. Proper storage practices should be followed to avoid post-harvest losses.
